newsitem.title: SPAIN: FOCUS - Spain unions table fresh offer to secure deal.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Spain unions table fresh offer to secure deal.

text.p: Spanish unions presented a new proposal to employers on Wednesday that could secure a deal on labour reforms before the government loses patience and imposes its own measures.

After a five-day break in talks, unions and employers resumed negotiations, eager to reach a prompt deal aimed at suppressing Spain's towering unemployment -- the highest in Europe at just under 22 percent.
Employers welcomed the unions' new offer and said the two sides were getting closer to an agreement.
"It appears to be an interesting proposal," Jose Maria Cuevas, head of the employers' association (CEOE) told reporters ahead of the talks.
Unions said they had proposed a new contract which met their demands for greater stability and sought to placate employers with lower dismissal costs.
"Our offer demonstrates our willingness to risk the maximum to defend the people who are unemployed," said Antonio Gutierrez, leader of the Workers' Commissions union (CCOO).
Employers said talks would now centre on the new proposal but the "cherry on the cake" would lie in severance pay.
"If (unions) think that it is along these lines that we can succed in reaching a deal, then we must proceed in that direction," Cuevas said.

The government has given unions and employers until early March to reach a deal before it steps in and forces an accord. But aware of the prickly nature of the issues, it has said it would be tolerant for the timebeing.
"Only when talks have completely broken down will the government directly intervene," Labour Minister Javier Arenas told a conference earlier this week.
Unions and employers reached a deadlock last Thursday over the key issue of contracts for young people.
Employers offered a new contract for under 27s which allowed for severance pay of 20 days per year worked.
But unions were not happy, and the two sides temporarily broke off talks to chew over the new proposals.
Now unions have come back with an offer not far from that presented by employers last week.
They are proposing a permanent contract that would provide severance pay for fair dismissal of 20 days for each year worked, with a maximum of 12 months.
In the event of unfair dismissal, the cost would be higher. While the exact figure remains vague, unions said it would be below the current 45 days per year, with a maximum of 42 months.

"The figure (for unfair dismissal) must be far enough away from the 42 months so that employers have some incentive to employ people on permanent contracts," Candido Mendez, leader of the General Workers' union (UGT), told a news conference.
"But it has to be sufficiently greater that 12 months so that...employers are dissuaded from firing."
Employers are keen to see dismissal costs cut. They complain Spain's severance pay is by far the highest in the European Union and dissuades them from hiring staff.
Unions, meanwhile, want to see the creation of a more secure contract, especially for youths who suffer most from unemployment in Spain.
